instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1708: What is A1708? A1708 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2017, 2016 with EMC 3164, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00840, 820-00875..
definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) Random Death
threads.message: Hello, I have a pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> that's unresponsive, the fan spins for a few seconds if I disconnect and connect the battery and the Amp pull keeps going up gradually 0.8-3.0, it seems dead but the trackpad vibrates when touch, 13v present on L7030, both 'CD3215COO' as well as the SSD get warm after a good few minutes. Any help would be appreciated, Thanks in advance.

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) Random Death
threads.message: forgot to mention it pulls 19.83V and 0.265A with just the board connected to power supply and everything else disconnected and there is a tiny water damage sign like a little drop between <RESISTOR>R8401</RESISTOR>-<RESISTOR>R8402</RESISTOR>

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) Random Death
threads.message:
Do you get L7210/20 voltage?
If yes, check for USB activity and external video.

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) Random Death
threads.message:
hi @
[B][USER=682]2informaticos[/USER] n[/B]o I have 0.250 on L7210

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) Random Death
threads.message: Post voltage for the other big coils...

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) Random Death
Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) Random Death
threads.message:
Post resistance to ground at L7370 (ohm scale).
Also check R/<CAPACITOR>C7379</CAPACITOR> and <RESISTOR>R7376</RESISTOR>.
If all OK, try known good BIOS...

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) Random Death
threads.message:
resistance to ground at L7370 >  5.73-77 OHMS
<RESISTOR>R7379</RESISTOR> resistance>>11.3 Mili ohms, will try a known good bios and update you

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) Random Death
threads.message: hi, the bios did not help its still the same, l7370 resistance is about 11+ohms now

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) Random Death
threads.message:
L7370 voltage must appear before L7210/20.
But all of them are controlled by same chip, <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>.
These voltages depends by BIOS, <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> and PCH/CPU.
Very likely bad CPU.

Did you test the board alone on the desk?
No SSD, nor LCD, or other devices; only charger connetced.

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) Random Death
threads.message: yes its the same thing with everything disconnected

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) Random Death
threads.message: I have similar issue with another <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> same board number, only one USB-C port was working, I replaced the port and now it does the same thing, Fan runs once when I reconnect the battery and the CPU and SSD warm up a bit but no display at all

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) Random Death
threads.message:
Stop considering the video as the only life sign.
Always check final CPU core voltage on these <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> boards.
Also USB activity is a must check ALWAYS.

About the second board, if was working before touching USB-C area, CPU core voltage appears now?
I suppose something was affected by the heat applied on that board...

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) Random Death
threads.message: what components do I check CPU core voltage on?

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) Random Death
threads.message:
L7210/20 in this case.
Check on the output pin, where the filter caps are placed.

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) Random Death
threads.message: CPU V core is 0v even on the other board (L7030 has 12.5V though)

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) Random Death
threads.message: I have Re Flashed the BIOS, it is still the same

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) Random Death
threads.message:
Board can't boot without CPU core voltage.
Check voltage on other big coils; of the second board.

For the future, open separate thread for different boards; even if the same models.
